datasetPresenter.name: AcarITEM5010_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus carbonarius resembles A. niger in many features, and indeed the two species are very closely related. A. carbonarius differs from A. niger most notably in the production of larger spores, although other minor morphological differences exist. The available information on its physiology indicates a broad similarity to A. niger. Recently, black aspergilli, mainly Aspergillus carbonarius and members of the Aspergillus niger aggregate, have been described as a main possible sources of ochratoxin (OTA) contamination in grapes from Argentina and Brazil, France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece and Australia as well as in dried vine fruits from different origins. Strong evidence of the contribution of A. carbonarius to the OTA contamination of wine has been also reported. Ochratoxin A is a highly harmful metabolite classified in 1993 by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC, 1993) as a possible human carcinogenic toxin (group 2B).
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from JGI.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
Annotation v3 (14 Dec 2009) is a consensus gene set predicted by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based , protein-based, and ab initio gene modelers. After filtering for homology and expression support, a total of 11624 genes were structurally and functionally annotated.
Assembly v3 (14 Dec 2009) is a 'hybrid' assembly of 454 and Sanger,gDNA reads improved by the JGI Finishing Pipeline. 963 scaffolds and 36.3 Mbp were assembled.

datasetPresenter.name: AclaNRRL1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus clavatus genome (strain NRRL1) has been sequenced by TIGR with funding provided by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID).

datasetPresenter.name: AflaNRRL3357_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus flavus genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.name: AfumAF293B_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data obtained from AspGD. The Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.name: AnidA4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data obtained from AspGD. The A nidulans genome was sequenced and annotated by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: AfumAF293B_mitochondrial_chromosome_AspGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data obtained from AspGD. The Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.name: AnigATCC1015_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015 annotaions was prepared by Hein Stam et al. from DSM, Netherlands

datasetPresenter.name: AterNIH2624_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus terreus NIH2624 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.name: BcinB0510_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Botrytis cinerea is a widespread phytopathogenic fungus which causes Gray-mold rot or Botrytis blight and affects most vegetable and fruit crops, as well as a large number of shrubs, trees, flowers, and weeds. It also has a beneficial role in the production of rare dessert wines, thus another name for Botrytis is "Noble Rot." This ascomycete's complex developmental lifecycle adds to the complexity in the classification and naming of this fungus.
datasetPresenter.description: The Botrytis cinerea (B05.10) genome sequence project was initiated by Syngenta AG. Whole Genome Shotgun (WGS) sequence reads from four plasmid libraries (2, 3, 10, and 14 kb) were provided by Syngenta to the Broad for assembly and submission of all data to GenBank.

datasetPresenter.name: BdenJEL423_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Batrachochytrium is a pathogen of amphibians implicated as a primary causative agent of amphibian declines. This recently emerging pathogen was identified in 1998 as the cause of amphibian deaths in Australia and Central America. More recently, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been implicated in population declines of frog species in North America, South America, Europe and Africa. This fungus invades the top layers of skin cells and causes thickening of the keratinized layer. As a representative of the Chytridiomycota (chytrids), the sequence of B. dendrobatidis is the first in this largely uncharacterized phylum of fungi.
datasetPresenter.description: The Broad Institute sequenced the diploid Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis strain JEL423 genome at 7.4X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The current assembly (Assembly 1) consists of 348 nuclear genome contigs in 69 supercontigs, and 3 mitochondrial genome contigs in 1 supercontig. The genome assembly will undergo automated annotation.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7.4X assembly was made public in September of 2006, and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future 2006 releases.

datasetPresenter.name: CalbSC5314_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The C. albicans strain SC5314 genome sequence and diploid contig-level assembly by the Stanford Genome Technology Center

datasetPresenter.name: CalbSC5314_mitochondrial_chromosome_CGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The C. albicans strain SC5314 genome sequence and diploid contig-level assembly by the Stanford Genome Technology Center

datasetPresenter.name: CcinOk7h130_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Coprinopsis cinerea, also known as Coprinus cinereus, is a multicellular basidiomycete that undergoes a complete sexual cycle, including typical mushroom formation. Extensive genetic and molecular analyses of this organism can be performed due to its easy cultivation on defined minimal media, making it a great model for studying development and regulation in multicellular organisms. The Coprinopsis cinerea genome is estimated at 37.5 Mb, organized in 13 chromosomes. Over 100 markers involved in mating type, hyphal growth, fruit body morphogenesis, and DNA repair have been assigned to 10 linkage groups. RFLP and RAPD markers are widely used.
datasetPresenter.description: The Coprinopsis cinerea reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coprinopsis cinerea strain okayama 7#130 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad institute. The Coprinopsis genome project is a partnership between the Broad Institute and the Coprinopsis research community. Genomic DNA for the genome project was provided by Patricia Pukkila at University of North Carolina.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from 4kb & 10kb plasmids and 40kb Fosmids.

datasetPresenter.name: CimmH5384_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: CimmRS_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: CgatR265_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
datasetPresenter.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

datasetPresenter.name: CgatWM276_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
datasetPresenter.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

datasetPresenter.name: CneoB3501_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: C neoformans B3501 was sequenced at the Stanford Genome Technology Center.

datasetPresenter.name: CneoH99_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: C neoformans H99 genome was annotated and submitted to Genbank by Fred Dietrich et al., from the Duke University

datasetPresenter.name: CneoJEC21_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: C neoformans JEC21 genome was annotated and submitted to Genbank by TIGR.

datasetPresenter.name: CposC735_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Reference sequence provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coccidiodes posadasii transgenic strain C735 delta SOWgp genome sequence submitted to INSDC by the J. Craig Venter Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: FgraPH1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium graminearum PH-1 genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: Foxy4287_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium oxysporum draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: Fver7600_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium verticillioides genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: HcapNAm1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).
datasetPresenter.description: The Ajellomyces capsulatus reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Ajellomyces capsulatus strain NAm1 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.protocol: For Histoplasma capsulatum class NAmI strain WU24, the Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in September 2005, and the results of automated genome annotation was made public May, 2006.

datasetPresenter.name: HcapG186AR_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).
datasetPresenter.description: The Washington University School of Medicine (WashU), in collaboration with the Broad Institute and the University of California at San Francisco, sequenced the Histoplasma capsulatum strain G186AR genome at 6X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing.
datasetPresenter.protocol: The Latin American Histoplasma capsulatum class H81 strain G186AR was assembled from sequence reads produced by both the Broad Institute and the Washington University School of Medicine. Sequences were obtained from 454 pOT library beads and fosmid libraries containing 3.1kb, 4.1kb, 5.7 kb, and 39kb inserts. The resulting 10X assembly was made public in May 2008 and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future releases.

datasetPresenter.name: HyaarEmoy2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Signatures of adaptation to obligate biotrophy in the Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome.
datasetPresenter.description: Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome sequenced and assembled at WashU genome center and Sainsbury lab and annotated at VBI. Please cite Baxter, Tripathy et. al Science(2010) Vol. 330 no. 6010 pp. 1549-1551

datasetPresenter.name: McirCBS27749_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Mucor circinelloides is a dimorphic fungus belonging to the Zygomycete class that has been studied in the laboratory for 35 years. Researchers have been attracted to it mainly because of its dimorphism, light responses, high capacity for accumulating lipids, anaerobic and aerobic production of ethanol and gene silencing mechanisms (RNAi). In the last few years the rate of knowledge acquisition in these fields has grown exponentially, and it is expected to grow even more in the future, due to the increasing number of molecular tools available to manipulate its genome, which allows the functional analysis of its genes. Mucor circinelloides is the fungus with the broadest molecular tool repertoire within the Zygomycota phylum. This includes genetic transformation using self-replicative plasmids, integrative transformation mediated by Agrobacterium, generation of knockout mutants and use of RNAi-based procedures to suppress gene function.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from JGI.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
Assembly v2 (28 Dec 2009) is an improved assembly produced by the JGI Finishing Pipeline. 26 scaffolds and 36.6 Mbp were assembled.
Annotation v2 (28 Dec 2009) is a consensus gene set predicted by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA-based, protein-based, and ab initio gene modelers, as well as Annotation v1 genes mapped onto the v2 scaffolds. After filtering for homology and expression support, a total of 11719 genes were structurally and functionally annotated.

datasetPresenter.name: MgloCBS7966_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Members of the genus Malassezia (formerly Pityrosporum) are lipophilic or lipid-dependent yeasts that are part of the normal cutaneous microflora. Considered opportunistic pathogens, they can cause systemic infection in neonates and are associated with multiple human skin disorders, including pityriasis versicolor (PV), psoriasis, atopic dermatitis (AD), seborrheic dermatitis (SD), dandruff, and Malassezia folliculitis. Malassezia globosa corresponds to the original description of Pityrosporum orbiculare and to the former serovar B of Malassezia furfur. It is commonly isolated from human scalp, and its mycelial form has been reported to cause PV.The Malassezia globosa genome is approximately 9 Mb.
datasetPresenter.description: The Malassezia globosa reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Malassezia globosa strain CBS 7966 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by The Procter & Gamble Company.

datasetPresenter.name: Mory7015_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Magnaporthe oryzae genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: NcraOR74A_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The approximately 40-megabase genome encodes about 10,000 protein-coding genes: more than twice as many as in the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe and only about 25% fewer than in the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster
datasetPresenter.description: The N crassa draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute in collaboration with the Neurospora research community.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
The genome sequence was assembled from deep whole-genome shotgun (WGS) coverage obtained by paired-end sequencing from a variety of clone types.
Sequencing methods for all clone types are described at http://www-genome.wi.mit.edu/. The sequence was assembled using Arachne

datasetPresenter.name: NcraOR74A_mitochondrial_chromosome_Broad_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The approximately 40-megabase genome encodes about 10,000 protein-coding genesâ€”more than twice as many as in the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe and only about 25% fewer than in the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster
datasetPresenter.description: N crassa draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute in collaboration with the Neurospora research community.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
The genome sequence was assembled from deep whole-genome shotgun (WGS) coverage obtained by paired-end sequencing from a variety of clone types.
Sequencing methods for all clone types are described at http://www-genome.wi.mit.edu/. The sequence was assembled using Arachne

datasetPresenter.name: Ndis8579_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The current draft release was submitted by John Taylor et al. from University of California, Berkeley. The gene models are predicted and functionally annotated using the JGI annotation pipeline

datasetPresenter.name: NfisNRRL181_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Neosartorya fischeri (aka Aspergillus fischeri), the closest relative of the major pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus, can cause keratitis, and pulmonary aspergillosis in transplant patients. Neosartorya fischeri (anamorph Aspergillus fischerianus) is a sexual Aspergillus species. This filamentous fungus is found in soil, and its spores are found in agricultural products.The haploid genome of Neosartorya fischeri is approximately 35 Mb, organized in eight chromosomes.
datasetPresenter.description: The Neosartorya fischeri reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is based on the genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by TIGR.

datasetPresenter.name: Ntet2508A_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: N. tetrasperma is the only Neurospora species that employs a mating strategy that combines selfing with occasional outbreeding using a novel genetic system (pseudohomothallism) and provides a model for studying both the genomic and evolutionary consequences of asexuality and inbreeding.
datasetPresenter.description: Neurospora tetrasperma was sequenced and annotated at the JGI and the project has been submitted to Genbank under accession number AFBT00000000

datasetPresenter.name: PchrRP78_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Phanerochaete chrysosporium has been the most intensively studied white rot fungus. White rot fungi secrete an array of peroxidases and oxidases that act non-specifically via the generation of lignin free radicals, which then undergo spontaneous cleavage reactions. The non-specific nature and exceptional oxidation potential of the enzymes has attracted considerable interest for application in bioprocesses such as organopollutant degradation and fiber bleaching.
Phanerochaete chrysosporium has several features that might make it very useful. First, unlike some white rot fungi, it leave the cellulose of the wood virtually untouched. Second, it has a very high optimum temperature (about 40 C), which means it can grow on wood chips in compost piles, which attain a very high temperature. These characteristics point to some possible roles in biotechnology.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from JGI.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
This draft was generated using a whole genome shotgun method. Genomic DNA was used to create six main libraries; four small insert (2 - 4 kb) pUC18 libraries, one medium insert (6 - 8 kb) pMCL200 library, and one large insert (35 - 40 kb) pCC1Fos library. A total of 611,025 end sequences were used in the assembly, corresponding to approximately 10.6X sequence depth.
v2.0 (February 2005): A total of 611,025 paired sequence fragments (10.6X coverage) were assembled with the JGI assembler, JAZZ. The assembly contains 35.1 million base pairs of non-redundant sequence in 232 scaffolds greater than 1 Kbp. 90% of the assembly was in 21 scaffolds, while 50% was found in 8 scaffolds longer than 1.9 Mbp.

datasetPresenter.name: PgraCRL75367003_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The pathogenic fungus Puccinia graminis causes stem rust in small cereal crops such as wheat, oat, rye, and barley. Stem rust, also referred to as black rust or black stem rust, is among the most destructive diseases of cereal crops and has resulted in enormous economic and yield losses. Puccinia graminis has a complex life cycle that includes five spore stages and two very different hosts, namely, a grass for the primary host and, most commonly, barberry as the alternate host. Puccinia graminis has a number of "special forms", or forma speciales (f. sp.), which differ in their primary host specificities.
datasetPresenter.description: The Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici strain CRL 75-36-700-3 genome sequence submitted to INSD by the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in January of 2007, and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future releases.

datasetPresenter.name: PhysoP6497_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Draft genome sequences of Phytophthora sojae and P. ramorum assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI. Please cite Tyler et al. (2006) Science. 313, 1261-1266

datasetPresenter.name: PhyraPr102_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Draft genome sequences of Phytophthora sojae and P. ramorum assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI. Please cite Tyler et al. (2006) Science. 313, 1261-1266

datasetPresenter.name: PhycaLT1534_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Phytophthora capsici is a highly dynamic and destructive pathogen of vegetables. It attacks all cucurbits, pepper, tomato and eggplant, and, more recently, snap and lima beans. Genome sequences were assembled and annotated at the JGI.

datasetPresenter.name: PhyinT304_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Phytophthora infestans genome sequences annotated at the Broad Institute. Please cite Haas and kamoun et al. Nature 461, 393-398.

datasetPresenter.name: PmarATCC18224_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Penicillium marneffei is a thermally dimorphic opportunistic fungal pathogen and thus can grow as an intracellular macrophage-associated fission yeast at 37 degree C, causing penicilliosis. This unique feature makes it the only pathogenic species of Penicillium within this taxon of more than 270 species. The infection is endemic in Southeast Asia and associated with immunocompromised individuals. It infects up to 10% of AIDS patients in this region and often result into a fatal systemic mycosis. The fungus is believed to be haploid, with at least seven chromosomes.
datasetPresenter.description: The Penicillium marneffei reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Penicillium marneffei strain ATCC 18224 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the J. Craig Ventor Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: PytulBR144_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Pythium ultimum is a ubiquitous oomycete plant pathogen responsible for a variety of diseases on a broad range of crop and ornamental species. Genome sequences were annotated at Michigan State University.Please cite Levesque et al. Genome Biol. 2010;11:R73.

datasetPresenter.name: Rory99880_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Rhizopus oryzae is a widely dispersed fungus that can cause fatal infections in people with suppressed immune systems, especially diabetics or organ transplant recipients. Antibiotic therapy alone is rarely curative, particularly in patients with disseminated infection. Broad sequenced the genome of a pathogenic R. oryzae strain and found evidence that the entire genome had been duplicated at some point in its evolution and retained two copies of three extremely sophisticated systems involved in energy generation and utilization. The ancient whole-genome duplication, together with recent gene duplications, has led to the expansion of gene families related to pathogen virulence, fungal-specific cell wall synthesis, and signal transduction, which may contribute to the aggressive and frequently life-threatening growth of this organism. Broad also identified cell wall synthesis enzymes, essential for fungal cell integrity but absent in mammals, which may present potential targets for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic treatments. R. oryzae represents the first sequenced fungus from the early lineages of the fungal phylogenetic tree, and thus the genome sequence sheds light on the evolution of the entire fungal kingdom.
datasetPresenter.description: The Rhizopus oryzae sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT.
datasetPresenter.protocol: The genome sequence was assembled from 454 Whole Genome Shotgun methods using fragment and paired-end reads to iteratively build the supercontigs. The annotation was performed using automated methods.

datasetPresenter.name: ScerS288c_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Saccharomyces cervisiae genome was obtained through the Saccharomyces Genome Database.

datasetPresenter.name: ScerS288c_genome_SGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Saccharomyces cervisiae genome was obtained through the Saccharomyces Genome Database.

datasetPresenter.name: ScerS288c_mitochondrial_chromosome_SGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: The Saccharomyces cervisiae genome was obtained through the Saccharomyces Genome Database.

datasetPresenter.name: SjapyFS275_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: A dimorphic fission yeast, capable of alternating between unicellular yeast form and multicellular true mycelium. Within the fission yeast clade, S. japonicus is an early diverging species and compared to S. pombe all 1:1 orthologs have an average amino acid identity of 55%. This fungus contain 10 families of gypsy-type retrotransposons, however a major loss of transposons occurred after the divergence of S. japonicus.The genome is organized in 3 chromosomes with a genome size estimated at ~11.5 Mb.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: SjapyFS275_mitochondrial_chromosome_Broad_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: A dimorphic fission yeast, capable of alternating between unicellular yeast form and multicellular true mycelium. Within the fission yeast clade, S. japonicus is an early diverging species and compared to S. pombe all 1:1 orthologs have an average amino acid identity of 55%. This fungus contain 10 families of gypsy-type retrotransposons, however a major loss of transposons occurred after the divergence of S. japonicus.The genome is organized in 3 chromosomes with a genome size estimated at ~11.5 Mb.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: SmacKhell_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Draft sequence of the Sordaria macrospora genome was prepared and submitted to GenBank by Minou Nowrousian, Jason Stajich et al.

datasetPresenter.name: SoctyFS286_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: A fission yeast most closely related to S. cryophilus and both sister to S. pombe with S. japonicus more distant and sister to all three species. The 1:1 orthologs of S. octosporus and S. cryophilus share 85% identity on average, similar to humans and dogs. This fission yeast's genome contains no transposons, but contains sequences related to reverse transcriptase and integrase that may represent extinct transposons. Telomere repeats (GGGTTACTT) matched a one-and-a-half repeat unit sequence at the putative telomerase-RNA locus, similar to the configuration in S. pombe (GGTTAC). There is no similarity between centromeric repeats in S. pombe and S. octosporus but karyotype (3 chromosomes) and pericentrometric gene order are conserved. The earlier diverging fission yeast S. japonicus contain 10 families of gypsy-type retrotransposons, however a major loss of transposons occurred after the divergence of S. japonicus. The retention of repetative elements in the centromeres of S. octosporus, S. cryophilus and S. pombe, despite having lost transposons, implies an important function for centromeric repeats.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: SoctyFS286_mitochondrial_chromosome_Broad_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: A fission yeast most closely related to S. cryophilus and both sister to S. pombe with S. japonicus more distant and sister to all three species. The 1:1 orthologs of S. octosporus and S. cryophilus share 85% identity on average, similar to humans and dogs. This fission yeast's genome contains no transposons, but contains sequences related to reverse transcriptase and integrase that may represent extinct transposons. Telomere repeats (GGGTTACTT) matched a one-and-a-half repeat unit sequence at the putative telomerase-RNA locus, similar to the configuration in S. pombe (GGTTAC). There is no similarity between centromeric repeats in S. pombe and S. octosporus but karyotype (3 chromosomes) and pericentrometric gene order are conserved. The earlier diverging fission yeast S. japonicus contain 10 families of gypsy-type retrotransposons, however a major loss of transposons occurred after the divergence of S. japonicus. The retention of repetative elements in the centromeres of S. octosporus, S. cryophilus and S. pombe, despite having lost transposons, implies an important function for centromeric repeats.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: Spom972hm_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from Pombase, European Bioinformatics Institute(EBI)

datasetPresenter.name: SreiSRZ2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Sporisorium reilianum is a biotrophic pathogen of maize and closely related to Ustilago maydis. The genomes of both fungi are highly syntenic but these two pathogens cause different symptoms on maize. U. maydis infection leads to formation of spore-filled tumors in the vicinity of the site of infection (on leaves, stems or flowers) whereas S. reilianum infect seedling plants and spread throughout the plant without noticeable impact on plant health until flowering when spore-filled sori appear in the inflorescences.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was obtained from Genbank. MIPS submitted the annotated genome.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Library construction and genome sequencing of S. reilianum strain SRZ2 was done at 454 Life Sciences (USA). As a first step a whole genome shotgun random library was constructed and sequenced using the Genome Sequencer 20 (Roche). In a second step, the genome was sequenced from a newly generated paired-end library of S. reilianum strain SRZ2 using the Genome Sequencer FLX (Roche). In a third step, the scaffold-assembly was verified by generating an NheI-based Optical Map (OpGen). Optical Mapping resulted in the assembly of 23 chromosomes on which 99.75% of the genome assembly could be placed. The total genome size based on Optical Mapping is estimated to be 18.7 Mb. Thus, the assembly contains 97 % of total sequence information.

datasetPresenter.name: Sscl1980_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Sclerotinia sclerotiorum (Lib.) de Bary is among the world's most successful and omnivorous fungal plant pathogens, with a host range of greater than 400 plant species. Despite decades of dedicated effort, resistant germplasm is still lacking in economically important crops. As an exemplar of soilborne pathogens and necrotrophic pathogenesis, S. sclerotiorum is a model for development of asexual, persistant propagules, somatic compatibility, and sexual sporulation. It is also central to a group of Ascomycetes with poorly known evolutionary relationships.
datasetPresenter.description: The Sclerotinia sclerotiorum reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Sclerotinia sclerotiorum strain 1980 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: TmesDSM1558_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Tremella species are jelly fungi found commonly associated with dead and decaying wood. Jelly fungi are heterobasidiomycetes and named according to their fruiting body structures, the consistency of which is similar to jelly. Of the Tremella sp., Tremella mesenterica has garnered the most attention: the key interest in T. mesenterica is the potential to derive fuel ethanol from lignocellulosic biomass. Identifying the factors responsible for degrading biomass is central to understanding the biological processes that impact bio-energy research. The biodegradation of wood components occurs in the presence of mostly wood rotting basidiomycetous fungi. T. mesenterica degrades lignin on decaying wood causing white rot disease, leaving the wood bleached or white in color. Lignin is an integral part of the plant cell wall and one of the most abundant biomolecules in the world next to cellulose. Lignin degradation also requires the presence of cellulose. The process occurs in two steps, saccharification and fermentation, which results in the production of fuel ethanol.
The key interest in fungi such as T. mesenterica is the potential to introduce an alternative mechanism, which aims to generate energy that is affordable, reliable, and environmentally sound. The T. mesenterica genome sequence will reveal factors required to mediate lignin degradation on wood. Fungi can then be bioengineered to degrade this biomolecule more efficiently to produce large quantities of fuel ethanol.
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data obtained from JGI.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
Draft assembly release version 1.0 of whole-genome shotgun reads was constructed at JGI with Arachne, using paired end sequencing reads at an average coverage of 7.44X.
The draft annotation release version 1.0 of the v1.0 assembly was produced by the JGI Annotation Pipeline, using a variety of cDNA/EST-based, homology-based, and ab initio gene predictors. After filtering for EST and homology support, a total of 8313 genes were structurally and functionally annotated. 77% of the genes have homology support, 52% have Pfam support, and 31% have EST support.

datasetPresenter.name: TreeQM6a_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Trichoderma reesei is an industrially important cellulolytic filamentous fungus. In light of of T. reesei's capacity to secrete large amounts of cellulases and hemi cellulases, the DOE is funding research into developing T. reesei as a host to produce low cost enzymes for the conversion of plant biomass materials into industrially useful bioproducts such as sugars and bioethanol.
As a system for studying genomics, T. reesei with its genome size of 33Mb and seven chromosomes has many advantages: EST and cDNA collections, BAC libraries available to academic researchers from the Fungal Genomics Laboratory at NCSU, DNA mediated transformation is a routine procedure, gene knockout protocols have been developed and there is an active academic community of researchers world-wide.
datasetPresenter.description: The Department of Energy (DOE) Joint Genome Institute sequenced the Trichoderma reesei strain QM6a genome using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The draft assembly currently consists of 170 scaffolds. The Trichoderma reesei genome is being finished at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

datasetPresenter.name: TstiATCC10500_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Talaromyces stipitatus is a non-pathogenic filamentous fungus that is the closest known relative of the pathogenic fungus Penicillium marneffei. Talaromyces stipitatus is saprophytic and is commonly found in soil, dung, and decaying plant material. It secretes several feruloyl esterases, which hydrolyze the ester bond between the hydroxycinnamic acids and sugars present in plant cell walls. These enzymes have several potential applications in the agri-food industries.
datasetPresenter.description: The Talaromyces stipitatus reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Talaromyces stipitatus ATCC 10500 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the J. Craig Venter Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: Umay521_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Ustilago maydis is a ubiquitous pathogen of maize and a well-established model organism for the study of plant-microbe interactions. This basidiomycete fungus does not use aggressive virulence strategies to kill its host. U. maydis belongs to the group of biotrophic parasites (the smuts) that depend on living tissue for proliferation and development.
The goal of this project is to release 10X genomic coverage for U. maydis strain 521. Bayer CropScience contributed their low-coverage genome sequence of U. maydis strain 521. These data consist of 17.4 Mb in 28 contigs and were generated from a minimal tiling path of overlapping BAC clones that cover 23 chromosomes. Exelixis has provided 5X whole-genome shotgun sequences of U. maydis strain FB1 that is assembled and aligned against the WGS assembly of strain 521 to identify polymorphism between these two strains.
datasetPresenter.description: The Ustilago maydis sequence project is part of the Broad Institute's Fungal Genome Initiative and was accomplished through collaborations with the Broad Institute, Bayer CropScience AG and Exelixis, Inc.
datasetPresenter.protocol: U. maydis strain 521 (a1 b1) was sequenced by two independent strategies, a whole genome shotgun (WGS) approach and a map-based sequencing strategy.

datasetPresenter.displayName: Wild Type, nrg1 KO, and nrg1 overexpression
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99 data from Teresea O'Meara et al. from Alspaugh Lab at Duke University on Wild Type, nrg1 KO, and nrg1 overexpression.

datasetPresenter.description: C.neoformans grubii H99 data from Brian Haynes et al. from Doering Lab at Washington University Medical School on ada2Δ, nrg1Δ and cir1Δ and KN99α wildtype expression.

datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcript Profiling Hyphal Growth Time Series
datasetPresenter.summary: Coprinopsis cineria hyphal growth on solid media at 2 time points: 9 days (taken at the hyphal edge) and 15 days (deeper into the colony).
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing hyphal sections from 2 time points (9 days and 15 days) of hyphal growth on solid media for Coprinopsis cinerea. This experiment is intended to compare genes expressed on the hyphal edge and in the colony.

templateInjector.prop: Transcript levels of fragments per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (FPKM). Stacked bars indicate unique and non-uniquely mapped sequences. Non-Unique sequences are plotted to indicate the maximum expression potential of this gene.

datasetPresenter.name: Rory99880_Stajich_hypalgrowth_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcript Profiling Hyphal Growth Time Series
datasetPresenter.summary: Rhizopus oryzae hyphal growth on solid media at 3 time points: 3 hrs, 5 hrs, and 20 hrs. The 3 hr timepoint is taken from the hyphal tip, while the 5 and 20 hr timepoints are taken from tissue deeper into the colony.
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3 hrs, 5 hrs, and 20 hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Rhizopus oryzae. The 3 hrs is the youngest tissue and from the hyphal tip while the 5 and 20 represent more interior to the colony and more mature tissue.

templateInjector.prop: Transcript levels of fragments per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (FPKM). Stacked bars indicate unique and non-uniquely mapped sequences. Non-Unique sequences are plotted to indicate the maximum expression potential of this gene.

datasetPresenter.name: CimmRS_Taylor_ComparativeTranscriptomics_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative Transcriptomics Rna Seq Expression Data
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases. The results highlighted a number of genes that may be crucial to dimorphic phase-switching and virulence in Coccidioides.
datasetPresenter.description: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases of Coccidiodes immitis and C. posadasii. Of the 9,910 total predicted genes in Coccidioides, 1,298 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the saprobic phase of both C. immitis and C. posadasii and 1,880 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the parasitic phase of both species
datasetPresenter.protocol: Illumina mRNA sequencing libraries for saprobic-phase hyphae and parasitic-phase spherules in vitro for C. immitis isolate RS and C. posadasii isolate C735 were prepared in biological triplicate

templateInjector.prop: Transcript levels of reads per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (RPKM). Stacked bars indicate unique and non-uniquely mapped sequences. Non-Unique sequences are plotted to indicate the maximum expression potential of this gene.

datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases. The results highlighted a number of genes that may be crucial to dimorphic phase-switching and virulence in Coccidioides.
datasetPresenter.description: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases of Coccidiodes immitis and C. posadasii. datasetPresenter.protocol: Illumina mRNA sequencing libraries for saprobic-phase hyphae and parasitic-phase spherules in vitro for C. immitis isolate RS and C. posadasii isolate C735 were prepared in biological triplicate

datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3hrs, 5hr, and 20hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Neurospora crassa.
datasetPresenter.protocol: This study compared gene expression from 3 different time points in hyphal growth by cutting 1 cm strip of tissue from the hyphal tip (3hrs old), several cm back (5hrs old) and further back in the colony (20hrs old) in Neurospora crassa OR74A growing on VM media.

datasetPresenter.name: NcraOR74A_Ellison_PopulationGenomics_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Neurospora crasss data from Christopher Ellison et al. from Taylor Lab at at UC Berkeley on whole-transcriptome sequencing of 48 individuals to identify SNPs
datasetPresenter.protocol: This study uses a "reverse-ecology" population genomic approach to identify ecologically relevant phenotypes in organisms that are difficult to study in nature.

datasetPresenter.name: CalbSC5314_Snyder_comprehensiveAnnotation_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Candida albicans data from Michael Snyder et al. from Synder Lab at Stanford University on Comprehensive Annotation of the transcriptome of the human fungal pathogen Candida albicans using RNA-Seq. Massively parallel high-throughput sequencing of cDNA was used to generate a high-resolution map of the C. albicans transcriptome under several different environmental conditions. The regions that are transcribed under the different conditions have been quantitatively determined and 635 novel transcriptionally active regions (TARs) and numerous novel introns have bben identified
datasetPresenter.protocol: Data has been generated for C. albicans (strain SC5314) grown under a total of nine different in vitro conditions. Using our data set of about 177 million mapped reads, we have significantly refined the primary annotations of the C. albicans genome by determining the position of transcripts in the genomes, including 602 newly identified transcripts for strain SC5314, and by identifying 41 new introns.

templateInjector.prop: Cellwall Damaging Environment, High Oxidative Stress, Low Oxidative Stress, Media Containing Serum, medium at PH4, medium at PH8, Nitrosative Stress, Non Cellwall Damage Environment, Non Nitrosative Environment, Non Oxidation Stress, YPD, YPD media, YPD media containing Serum

Transcript levels of reads per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (RPKM). Stacked bars indicate unique and non-uniquely mapped sequences. Non-Unique sequences are plotted to indicate the maximum expression potential of this gene.

datasetPresenter.name: Spom972hm_Barraud_dicerProtein_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Schizosaccharomyces pombe data from Pierre Barraud, Marc Buhler et al. from ETH Zurich and FMI Basel on nuclear retention of fission yeast Dicer. Dicer proteins function in RNA interference (RNAi) pathways by generating small RNAs (sRNAs). The solution structure of the C-terminal domain of Schizosaccharomyces pombe Dicer (Dcr1) is reported here. The C-terminal domain of Dcr1 constitutes a novel regulatory module that might represent a potential target for therapeutic intervention with fungal diseases.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Small RNA libraries from total RNA isolations of wild-type, dcr1Delta, dcr1SHSS, and dcr1Deltaloop2 cells and subjected to high-throughput sequencing.

templateInjector.prop: Transcript levels of reads per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (RPKM). Stacked bars indicate unique and non-uniquely mapped sequences. Non-Unique sequences are plotted to indicate the maximum expression potential of this gene.

datasetPresenter.summary: Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data
datasetPresenter.description: The following experiments from Spellman et. al. : (1) Pheromone synchronization time course, (2) Size-based synchronization time course (elutriation), (3) Cdc15-based synchronization time course, (4) Transcriptional response to the cyclins Cln3p and Clb2p. The following experiment is from Cho et. al. Cdc28-based synchronization time course

templateInjector.prop: The expression value is log2(sample/common reference)

datasetPresenter.name: PhysoP6497_Physo_rnaseq_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: This study has 2 experimental replicates and each one has 4 biological replicates. The first replicate is from P. sojae mycelial tissue sample grown in media and the second replicate is from Soybean hypocotyls infected with P. sojae 3 dpi.

datasetPresenter.description: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling in zoospore, chlamydospore , V8 medium and tomato broth

datasetPresenter.description: Illumina sequencing was performed using RNA from four week old Arabidopsis Ws-2 eds1-1 leaves, highly colonized with Emoy2, at 7 days post-inoculation at 60% humidity to promote mycelial growth in the mesophyll over sporulation.

datasetPresenter.name: AfumAF293B_SNP_JCVI_HTS_SNP_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was provided by JCVI and obtained from NCBI SRA.

datasetPresenter.name: AfumAF293B_SNP_JCVI_HTS_SNP_PE_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Sequencing data was provided by JCVI and obtained from NCBI SRA. J. Craig Venter Institute, in collaboration with Celera Genomics, sequenced the Aspergillus fumigatus strain A1163 genome at 10X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing.

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_dbxref_unity_CGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Candida Genome Database (CGD)
datasetPresenter.description: Candida Genome Database (CGD) is a resource for genomic sequence data and gene and protein information for Candida albicans. CGD is based on the Saccharomyces Genome Database and is funded by the National Institute of Dental & Craniofacial Research at the US National Institutes of Health.

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_dbxref_unity_AspGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Aspergillus Genome Database (AspGD)
datasetPresenter.description: AspGD is an organized collection of genetic and molecular biological information about the filamentous fungi of the genus Aspergillus.

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_dbxref_unity_CADRE_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The Central Aspergillus REsource (CADRE)
datasetPresenter.description: CADRE aims to support the international Aspergillus research community by gathering all genomic information regarding this significant genus into one resource. CADRE facilitates visualisation and analyses of data using the Ensembl software suite.

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_dbxref_unity_FGSC_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Fungal Genetics Stock Center (FGSC)
datasetPresenter.description: The Fungal Genetics Stock Center is a resource available to the Fungal Genetics research community and to educational and research organizations in general. (It) was established to preserve strains that were finding important use in genetics research. The concern was present in the Fungal Genetics research community that strains used in the 40's and 50's were in danger of being lost as the researchers who had generated them retired or moved on to other areas of inquiry.

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_dbxref_unity_SGD_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Saccharomyces Genome Database (SGD)
datasetPresenter.description: The Saccharomyces Genome Database (SGD) provides comprehensive integrated biological information for the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae along with search and analysis tools to explore these data, enabling the discovery of functional relationships between sequence and gene products in fungi and higher organisms.

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_dbxref_unity_EnsemblFungi_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: EnsemblFungi
datasetPresenter.description: Ensembl Genomes is developed by EMBL-EBI and is powered by Ensembl software system for the analysis and visualisation of genomic data.

templateInjector.prop: (exprn_val) left - differential expression value, right - expression fold change; (percentile) Ranking percentile of intensity, relative to all other genes
